title: Authors and Citation
Authors and Citation
text: Navarro D (2025). calendario: Minimal Task Tracker. R package version 0.0.0.9016, https://calendario.djnavarro.net.
code: @Manual{,   title = {calendario: Minimal Task Tracker},   author = {Danielle Navarro},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9016},   url = {https://calendario.djnavarro.net}, }

title: Minimal Task Tracker
text: Personal package help track tasks. Unlikely value anyone else.

title: Minimal Task Tracker
text: can install development version calendario like :

title: Minimal Task Tracker
text: Creating calendar adding tasks projects: Viewing tasks, projects, monthly calendars:
code: library(calendario)  # initialise an empty calendar cal <- Calendario$new() cal #> <Calendario object [0 projects]>  # this is the verbose way to add a task cal$add_task(   description = "it's a thing",   start = as.Date("2025-07-11"),   stop = as.Date("2025-07-14"),   project = "be gay",   team  = "danielle" ) cal #> <Calendario object [1 project]> #> • be gay [1 task]  # this is a more convenient way cal$set_project("do crime") cal$add_task("crime 1", "12 jul") cal$add_task("crime 2", "12 jul", "14 jul") cal #> <Calendario object [2 projects]> #> • be gay [1 task] #> • do crime [2 tasks]  # piping is also supported cal |>   cal_set_project("be happy") |>   cal_add_task("thing 1", "2 jul") |>   cal_add_task("thing 2", "13 jul") cal  #> <Calendario object [3 projects]> #> • be gay [1 task] #> • be happy [2 tasks] #> • do crime [2 tasks] # extracting tasks returns a tibble cal$get_tasks() #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   project  type  description  start      stop       hours team     #>   <chr>    <chr> <chr>        <date>     <date>     <dbl> <chr>    #> 1 be gay   work  it's a thing 2025-07-11 2025-07-14     2 danielle #> 2 do crime work  crime 1      2025-07-12 2025-07-12     2 danielle #> 3 do crime work  crime 2      2025-07-12 2025-07-14     2 danielle #> 4 be happy work  thing 1      2025-07-02 2025-07-02     2 danielle #> 5 be happy work  thing 2      2025-07-13 2025-07-13     2 danielle  # showing tasks returns a flextable cal$show_tasks() # extracting a calendar returns a list of tibbles cal$get_calendar("1 jun", "11 aug") #> [[1]] #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   Month Days    Mon   Tue   Wed   Thu   Fri #>   <ord> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Jun   2-6       0     0     0     0     0 #> 2 Jun   9-13      0     0     0     0     0 #> 3 Jun   16-20     0     0     0     0     0 #> 4 Jun   23-27     0     0     0     0     0 #> 5 Jun   30        0    NA    NA    NA    NA #>  #> [[2]] #> # A tibble: 5 × 7 #>   Month Days    Mon   Tue   Wed   Thu   Fri #>   <ord> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Jul   1-4      NA     0     2     0     0 #> 2 Jul   7-11      0     0     0     0     2 #> 3 Jul   14-18     4     0     0     0     0 #> 4 Jul   21-25     0     0     0     0     0 #> 5 Jul   28-31     0     0     0     0    NA #>  #> [[3]] #> # A tibble: 3 × 7 #>   Month Days    Mon   Tue   Wed   Thu   Fri #>   <ord> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Aug   1        NA    NA    NA    NA     0 #> 2 Aug   4-8       0     0     0     0     0 #> 3 Aug   11        0    NA    NA    NA    NA  # showing a calendar returns a flextable cal$show_calendar("1 jun", "11 aug")

code: Calendario$add_task(   description = NULL,   start = NULL,   stop = NULL,   hours = NULL,   type = NULL,   project = NULL,   team = NULL )

title: R6 Class Representing Tasks and Projects — Calendario
text: description Character string providing description task start Date work starts (defaults current date) stop Date work stops (defaults day start) hours Number hours per day task takes type Character string assigning task category project Character string naming project task falls within team Character string describing team

title: R6 Class Representing Tasks and Projects — Calendario
code: cal <- Calendario$new() cal$add_task(   description = "label for the task",   start = as.Date("2025-01-24"),   stop = as.Date("2025-01-26"),   hours = 1,   project = "my project",   team = "just me" ) cal$get_tasks()

what: Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
title: Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
text: cal_add_task(), cal_set_project(), functions convenience functions allow piped workflow calendario objects

title: Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
text: x calendario object ... Arguments passed relevant R6 method

title: Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
text: functions wrappers around one calendario object methods: cal_add_task() wrapper around $add_task(), cal_set_project() wrapper around $set_project() . cases functions take calendario object x first argument, arguments passed via ... relevant calendario R6 method.

title: Wrapper functions for calendario methods — wrappers
code: cal <- Calendario$new() cal |>   cal_set_project("project-name") |>   cal_add_task("description-1", "29 may") |>   cal_add_task("description-2", "1 jun") |>   cal_get_workload() cal$get_tasks() #> # A tibble: 2 × 7 #>   project      type  description   start      stop       hours team     #>   <chr>        <chr> <chr>         <date>     <date>     <dbl> <chr>    #> 1 project-name work  description-1 2025-05-29 2025-05-29     2 danielle #> 2 project-name work  description-2 2025-06-01 2025-06-01     2 danielle
